sections.universal consistency:
The basis of our framework is a universal consistency problem which can be instantiated to simulate a particular memory model.
For its formulation, we make use of a consistency notion that allows for the construction of a fast algorithm but deviates from the literature    at first sight.
Therefore, it is proven in Section 4 that instantiating the problem with a particular memory model yields the correct notion of consistency. We clarify our notion of consistency.
Intuitively, a history is consistent under a memory model if it can be scheduled such that certain axioms defined by the model are satisfied.
Following the formal framework of  , finding such a schedule amounts to finding a particular order of the write events that satisfies acyclicity requirements imposed by the axioms.
Formally, let h=⟨O,𝑝𝑜,𝑟𝑓⟩ℎ𝑂𝑝𝑜𝑟𝑓h=\langle O,\mathit{po},\mathit{rf}\rangle be a history and let \ComplexityFont​M​M\ComplexityFont𝑀𝑀\ComplexityFont{MM} be a memory model described by the tuple (𝑝𝑜​-​𝑚𝑚,𝑟𝑓​-​𝑚𝑚)𝑝𝑜-𝑚𝑚𝑟𝑓-𝑚𝑚(\mathit{po}\,\text{-}\mathit{mm},\mathit{rf}\text{-}\mathit{mm}).
Then hℎh is called \ComplexityFont​M​M\ComplexityFont𝑀𝑀\ComplexityFont{MM}-consistent if there exists a strict total order 𝑡𝑤𝑡𝑤\mathit{tw} on the write events 𝑊𝑅𝑊𝑅\!\mathit{WR} of hℎh such that the graphs are both acyclic.
Here, the conflict relation 𝑐𝑓𝑐𝑓\mathit{cf} is defined by 𝑐𝑓=𝑟𝑓−1∘⋃x∈𝑉𝑎𝑟𝑡𝑤x𝑐𝑓superscript𝑟𝑓1subscript𝑥𝑉𝑎𝑟subscript𝑡𝑤𝑥\mathit{cf}=\mathit{rf}^{-1}\circ\bigcup_{x\in\!\mathit{Var}}\mathit{tw}_{x}.
Phrased differently, (r,w)∈𝑐𝑓𝑟𝑤𝑐𝑓(r,w)\in\mathit{cf} if r𝑟r is a read event on a variable x𝑥x, w𝑤w is a write event on x𝑥x, and there is a write event w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} on x𝑥x such that (w′,r)∈𝑟𝑓superscript𝑤′𝑟𝑟𝑓(w^{\prime},r)\in\mathit{rf} and (w′,w)∈𝑡𝑤superscript𝑤′𝑤𝑡𝑤(w^{\prime},w)\in\mathit{tw}. The acyclicity of G𝑙𝑜𝑐subscript𝐺𝑙𝑜𝑐G_{\mathit{loc}} is called uniprocessor requirement  or memory coherence for each location .
Roughly, it demands that an order among writes to the same location that can be extracted from the history, is kept in 𝑡𝑤𝑡𝑤\mathit{tw}.
The second acyclicity requirement in the definition resembles the underlying memory model \ComplexityFont​M​M\ComplexityFont𝑀𝑀\ComplexityFont{MM}.
If G𝑚𝑚subscript𝐺𝑚𝑚G_{\mathit{mm}} is acyclic, the history can be scheduled adhering to the axioms defined by \ComplexityFont​M​M\ComplexityFont𝑀𝑀\ComplexityFont{MM}. Our definition of consistency deviates from the literature in two aspects.
First, we demand a total order 𝑡𝑤𝑡𝑤\mathit{tw} instead of a store order, a partial order that is total on writes to the same location   .
In Section 4 we will show that the resulting notions of consistency are equivalent.
A further difference is that we do not explicitly test for out of thin air values [ref]41.
For the majority of memory models considered in this work, the test is not necessary as it is implied by the acyclicity of G𝑙𝑜𝑐subscript𝐺𝑙𝑜𝑐G_{\mathit{loc}} and G𝑚𝑚subscript𝐺𝑚𝑚G_{\mathit{mm}}.
But it can easily be added when needed. We are ready to state the universal consistency problem.
To this end, let \ComplexityFont​M​M\ComplexityFont𝑀𝑀\ComplexityFont{MM} be a fixed memory model.
Given a history hℎh, the problem asks whether hℎh is \ComplexityFont​M​M\ComplexityFont𝑀𝑀\ComplexityFont{MM}-consistent.
{myproblem}




Instantiations of the problem by well-known memory models like \SC\SC\SC or \ComplexityFont​T​S​O\ComplexityFont𝑇𝑆𝑂\ComplexityFont{TSO} are typically \NP\NP\NP-hard  .
However, we are interested in a deterministic algorithm for \ComplexityFontMM-Consistency.
While we cannot avoid an exponential running time for such an algorithm, a fine-grained complexity analysis can determine the optimal exponential dependence.
Many parameters of \ComplexityFontMM-Consistency like the number of threads, the maximum size per thread, or the size of the data domain yield parameterizations that are \W​\Wdelimited-[]1\W-hard  .
Therefore, we conduct a fine-grained analysis for the parameter k=|𝑊𝑅|𝑘𝑊𝑅k=|\!\mathit{WR}|, the number of writes in hℎh.
The main finding is an algorithm for \ComplexityFontMM-Consistency running in time 𝒪∗​(2k)superscript𝒪superscript2𝑘\mathcal{O}^{*}(2^{k}).
The optimality of this approach is shown in Section 5 by a complementing lower bound.
We formally state the upper bound in the following theorem.
There, n=|O|𝑛𝑂n=|O| denotes the number of events in hℎh. The problem \ComplexityFont​M​M\ComplexityFont𝑀𝑀\ComplexityFont{MM}-Consistency can be solved in time 𝒪​(2k⋅k2⋅n2)𝒪⋅superscript2𝑘superscript𝑘2superscript𝑛2\mathcal{O}(2^{k}\cdot k^{2}\cdot n^{2}). Note that an algorithm for \ComplexityFontMM-Consistency running in time 𝒪∗​(kk)superscript𝒪superscript𝑘𝑘\mathcal{O}^{*}(k^{k}) is immediate.
One can iterate over all total orders of 𝑊𝑅𝑊𝑅\!\mathit{WR} and check the acyclicity of G𝑙𝑜𝑐subscript𝐺𝑙𝑜𝑐G_{\mathit{loc}} and G𝑚𝑚subscript𝐺𝑚𝑚G_{\mathit{mm}} in polynomial time.
Since we cannot afford this iteration in 𝒪∗​(2k)superscript𝒪superscript2𝑘\mathcal{O}^{*}(2^{k}), improving the running time needs an alternative approach and further technical development that we summarize in Section 3.2.
